title: Single Sign-On (SSO)
ques: What is the main benefit of **SSO** for an enterprise environment?

answer.content:
**SSO** allows a user to log in **once** (e.g., to their Google or Microsoft work account) and automatically gain access to all authorized applications (Slack, Zoom, Jira) without entering credentials again for each one.

**Benefit:** Improves user experience/productivity and reduces 'password fatigue'.

explanation: It also simplifies disabling access when an employee leaves (just disable one central account).

title: SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language)

answer.content:
**SAML** is an XML-based standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data between an **Identity Provider (IdP)** and a **Service Provider (SP)**.

It is the dominant standard for legacy enterprise SSO.

explanation: Modern web apps are moving towards OIDC, but SAML is still huge in corporate IT.

title: Identity Provider (IdP)
ques: In an SSO setup, what is the role of the **Identity Provider (IdP)**?

answer.content:
The **IdP** is the trusted service that holds the user directory and verifies credentials.

**Examples:** Okta, Auth0, Google Workspace, Azure AD.

The application (Service Provider) trusts the IdP to say 'This is John Doe, and he is authenticated'.

explanation: The app outsources 'logging in' to the IdP.

title: Social Login vs Enterprise SSO
ques: Is 'Log in with Facebook' considered SSO?

answer.content:
**Yes.**

It works on the same principle as Enterprise SSO. Facebook acts as the Identity Provider. You authenticate with Facebook, and they vouch for your identity to the third-party app (Spotify, Pinterest, etc.).
